name: Volkswagen Polo R WRC
details_html: Debuting in 2013, the Polo R WRC won 4 straight manufacturers’ titles and dominated with Sébastien Ogier, becoming one of the most successful cars in WRC history.

name: Ford Fiesta RS WRC (2011–2016)
details_html: Ford’s factory entry post-Focus, the Fiesta RS WRC was driven by Ogier, Latvala, and later Tänak. It helped M-Sport win back-to-back drivers’ titles in 2017–2018.

name: Hyundai i20 WRC
details_html: Hyundai’s modern rally return began with the i20 WRC. It became increasingly competitive throughout the decade, delivering wins for Neuville and Paddon.

name: Citroën DS3 WRC
details_html: Replacing the C4, the DS3 WRC carried Loeb to his final two titles and gave Citroën multiple wins before falling behind the new-generation cars.

name: Toyota Yaris WRC
details_html: Toyota’s comeback car from 2017 onward, the Yaris WRC won multiple events and the 2018 manufacturers’ title with Tänak, Latvala, and Lappi.

name: Citroën C3 WRC
details_html: The C3 WRC replaced the DS3 in 2017. Though inconsistent, it scored wins with Meeke and a memorable 2018 victory for Loeb in Spain.

name: Mini John Cooper Works WRC
details_html: Mini’s short-lived WRC return in 2011–2012 with the JCW WRC showed flashes of potential, but funding and reliability limited its success.
